    Discovery of a Novel Inhibitor of Histone Lysine-Specific Demethylase 1A (KDM1A/LSD1) as Orally Active Antitumor Agent

    • Paola Vianello*†
      • , 
    • Oronza A. Botrugno†
      • , 
    • Anna Cappa†
      • , 
    • Roberto Dal Zuffo†

    • Paola Dessanti†

    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    We report the stereoselective synthesis and biological activity of a novel series of tranylcypromine (TCPA) derivatives (14a–k, 15, 16), potent inhibitors of KDM1A. The new compounds strongly inhibit the clonogenic potential of acute leukemia cell lines. In particular three molecules (14d, 14e, and 14g) showing selectivity versus MAO A and remarkably inhibiting colony formation in THP-1 human leukemia cells, were assessed in mouse for their preliminary pharmacokinetic. 14d and 14e were further tested in vivo in a murine acute promyelocytic leukemia model, resulting 14d the most effective. Its two enantiomers were synthesized: the (1S,2R) enantiomer 15 showed higher activity than its (1R,2S) analogue 16, in both biochemical and cellular assays. Compound 15 exhibited in vivo efficacy after oral administration, determining a 62% increased survival in mouse leukemia model with evidence of KDM1A inhibition. The biological profile of compound 15 supports its further investigation as a cancer therapeutic.

    SPECIAL ISSUE

    This article is part of the Epigenetics special issue.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Over the past 2 decades, the relevance of epigenetic modifications for transcriptional control and normal development, as well as the role of such modifications in cancer development and progression, has attracted a great deal of attention.(1-3) Histone lysine methylation, a dynamic and accurately regulated mechanism,(4, 5) represents one of the several post-translation modifications controlling chromatin conformation and gene transcription.(6) Two enzyme families, lysine methyltransferases (KMTs)(7) and demethylases (KDMs),(8, 9) control histone lysine methylation. KDMs encompass the Jumonji C (JmjC) domain-containing proteins(8) and the lysine specific demethylase (LSD) family.(9)
    Two lysine specific demethylase proteins have been identified to date: KDM1A (LSD1), a flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD) dependent amino oxidase, which was the first discovered histone lysine demethylase,(10) and its homologous KDM1B (LSD2).(11) KDM1A is often found associated with protein complexes functioning as transcriptional repressors, such as CoRest,(12-14) and with the nucleosome remodeling and deacetylation complex Nurd.(15, 16) Consistently, KDM1A demethylates mono and dimethyl histone 3 lysine 4 (H3K4me1, H3K4me2), which are marks associated with active gene transcription.(17)
    In addition, KDM1A has been found in complexes involved in active gene transcription and reported to change its substrate specificity from H3K4me1/me2 to mono and dimethyl histone H3 lysine 9 (H3K9me1/me2), once associated with estrogen and androgen nuclear receptors.(18, 19) KDM1A has also been found in protein complexes involved in transcription elongation such as the ELL complex(20) and the MLL supercomplex.(21)
    The H3K4 demethylase activity of KDM1A can be influenced by histone post-translational modifications such as acetylation(22) and phosphorylation.(23) In particular, both histone H3 lysine 9 acetylation (H3K9Ac) and histone H3 serine 10 phosphorylation (H3S10p)(23) can strongly reduce or block KDM1A demethylase activity.
    Several non-histone substrates of KDM1A have been identified.(24-28) For instance, KDM1A demethylates and stabilizes DNA methyl transferase 1 (DNMT1),(27) E2F1,(23) and STAT3.(28) Furthermore, KDM1A demethylates the myosin phosphatase MYPT1, a phosphatase involved in Rb dephosphorylation,(24) as well as repressing p53 function through the inhibition of its interaction with 53BP1.(25)
    High KDM1A expression correlates with poor prognosis in several tumor types such as neuroblastoma,(29) prostate cancer,(18, 30) non-small-cell lung cancer,(31) breast cancer,(32, 33) esophageal squamous cancer,(34) and hepatocellular carcinoma.(35) Bladder cancer(36) and colorectal cancer(37) are also characterized by elevated KDM1A expression. Notably, KDM1A was recently proposed to confer stem-cell-like characteristics to breast cancer cells(38) as well as maintain stem-cell-like tumor propagating cells in human glioblastoma.(39) In hematopoietic and lymphoid neoplasias, high expression of KDM1A has been observed in acute myeloid leukemia,(40) myeloproliferative neoplasms, chronic myelomonocytic leukemia, and myelodysplastic syndromes.(41) In addition, strong experimental evidence supports a role for KDM1A in the self-renewal of leukemic stem cells in acute myeloid leukemia (AML) and, more specifically, in the promotion of the oncogenic gene program associated with MLL-AF9 leukemia.(42)
    The link between KDM1A and tumor pathogenesis, and the discovery that the monoamine oxidase (MAO) inhibitor tranylcypromine (TCPA) blocks KDM1A activity,(22) represented the starting point for intensive drug discovery programs aimed at the development of irreversible TCPA-based KDM1A inhibitors.(43-56) Two TCPA derivatives (Figure 1), N4-[(1R,2S)-2-phenylcyclopropyl]cyclohexane-1,4-diamine (22, ORY1001/RG-6016)(57-59) and 4-[[4-[[[(1R,2S)-2-phenylcyclopropyl]amino]methyl]-1-piperidyl]methyl]benzoic acid (23, GSK2879552),(60-62) both characterized by nitrogen substitution at the core of TCPA, are currently under clinical investigation. In addition, several reversible inhibitors of KDM1A have been identified by different research groups.(63)
    In a previous manuscript, we showed that substitutions on the phenyl moiety of TCPA allowed the identification of highly active KDM1A inhibitors.(64) Among these, compound 1 (4-benzamidocyclopropylamine; 13b in ref 64) (Figure 2) was demonstrated to be a potent KDM1A inhibitor, while its ortho and meta regioisomers exhibited a lower activity against KDM1A.(65) The enantiomers of compound 1 displayed potent KDM1A inhibition, with IC50 values of 13 and 26 nM, as well as anticlonogenic activity in primary murine acute promyelocytic leukemia blasts. These results prompted us to expand the scaffold with the aim to obtain compounds with a better selectivity profile toward MAO A and good activity in a human cellular model of MLL-AF9 leukemia (THP-1 cells). Compound 14d was found to be the most promising derivative in this respect, and its biological properties encouraged the synthesis of its two enantiomers. We report herein the stereoselective synthesis of the two enantiomers (Scheme 1) together with their in vitro and in vivo characterization.

    Results and Discussion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Chemistry

    The synthesis of the final compounds 14a–k, 15, and 16 (Figure 3) was carried out following two routes. According to Scheme 1 (method A), the oxirane 2 and its 2-S (3) and 2-R (4) analogues were added to a solution of triethyl phosphonoacetate and butyllithium in dimethoxyethane and the reaction was microwave irradiated to 130 °C, affording the ethyl esters of 2-phenylcyclopropanecarboxylic acids. Subsequent hydrolysis of the ethyl esters with LiOH provided the carboxylic acids 5–7, which were treated with iodine in acetic acid yielding the 4-iodo derivatives 8–10. The protected amino derivatives 11–13 were subsequently obtained by reaction of the iodo derivatives 8–10 with diphenyl phosphorazidate (DPPA) in the presence of triethylamine and in tert-butanol at 90 °C. Ullman reaction with primary amides and subsequent BOC deprotection with hydrochloric acid afforded the cyclopropylamines 14a–g, 15, and 16 as their hydrochloride salts.
    According to Scheme 2 (method B), the appropriate acids 18h–k were activated by benzotriazol-1-yloxytripyrrolidinophosphonium hexafluorophosphate (PyBOP) or 1-(3-dimethylaminopropyl)-3-ethylcarbodiimide (EDC) in the presence triethylamine and condensated with tert-butyl N-[2-(4-aminophenyl)cyclopropyl]carbamate 17.(64) The final compounds 14h–k were smoothly obtained by removing Boc protection with hydrochloric acid in dioxane.
    The carboxylic acid or primary amide intermediates were prepared according to Schemes 3 and 4 when not commercially available.
    The synthesis of bisubstituted acids 18h–k is reported in Scheme 3. tert-Butyl chloronitrobenzoates(66) were converted into 19h–k by reaction with morpholine, 4-methylpiperazine, or piperidine in the presence of K2CO3. Reduction of the nitro group to the amine in compounds 20h–k was achieved by conventional catalytic hydrogenation, e.g., in a Parr hydrogenation or H-Cube apparatus using a palladium catalyst. The carbamates 21h–k were then obtained by reacting the free amines 20h–k with benzyl chloroformate in the presence triethylamine at room temperature. Finally, the tert-butyl ester group was hydrolyzed with TFA (trifluoroacetic acid) in dichloromethane.
    The benzamides 19e,f were prepared according to Scheme 4. The commercially available 3- or 4-(2-oxo-1,3-oxazolidin-3-yl)benzoic acids 18e and 18f were first activated with thionyl chloride and then converted into the amides 19e,f with aqueous NH3 in DMF.

    Biological Evaluation and SAR

    Benzamido derivatives of TCPA have been previously described, reporting that the para substituted is more potent than the ortho and meta isomers.(56, 64, 65) Substituents on the phenyl ring of compound 1 were directed toward a major occupancy of the binding pocket, without impacting drug-like properties of the molecules, thus maintaining solubility at an acceptable level. For this purpose, both aliphatic (piperazine, morpholine, piperidine oxazolidin-2-one) and aromatic (furane) heterocycles were prioritized among the set of most frequently used ring systems present in small molecule drugs.(67) Alternatively or concurrently we introduced a carbobenzyloxy residue which could either impact the stereoelectronic features of the benzamide end side or branch the molecule to modulate selectivity versus MAOs.(56) As summarized in Table 1 the final compounds 14a–k as well as the reference compound 22 were profiled in vitro for their KDM1A, KDM1B, MAO A and B inhibitory activities. To this end human recombinant KDM1A/CoREST and KDM1B as well as MAO A and MAO B proteins were employed as enzymatic sources. The compounds were incubated with the enzymatic complex, and the results are expressed as IC50 values.
    Table 1. Biochemical Profile of Compounds 1, 14a–k, and 22
    Table a

    Data are expressed as the mean of at least two determinations ± standard deviation. IC50 curves of biochemical assay are supplied as Supporting Information.

    The introduction of different residues did not lead to further increase in KDM1A inhibitory activity, the most potent being the equipotent furan-bearing 14a (IC50 = 0.022 μM compared to 0.019 μM of compound 1). However, all compounds showed IC50 values equal to or less than 0.1 μM, with the exception of compound 14k (IC50 = 0.308 μM). Similarly, substitution in meta versus para did not influence the inhibitory potency of KDM1A (14e vs 14f), whereas the use of carbobenzyloxy group gave a 2 fold less potent derivative 14b, which slightly improved in its cyclized analogue meta oxazolidin-2-one 14e. The para oxazolidin-2-one derivative 14f was 2 times more potent than the morpholine analogue 14c, which in turn was 3 fold more potent than piperazine 14d. Furthermore, substitution of the benzamide, in particular by a 3-benzyloxycarbonylamino (3-CBZ) moiety, resulted in an increased KDM1B inhibitory activity. Specifically, compound 1 exhibited an IC50 value of 58.3 μM, the 3-CBZ substituted derivative 14b was to be roughly 5 times more active (IC50 = 11.6 μM), while the disubstituted inhibitors 14h, 14j, and 14k had IC50 values of around 5 μM. With the exception of 14a, having an IC50 value of 0.09 μM, all other compounds were selective over MAO B: in particular, compounds 14b, 14g, and 14j did not show any MAO B inhibitory activity under the employed experimental conditions. We hypothesized that the higher activity of 14a versus MAO B can be related to the aromaticity of the furan, which finds an ideal environment in the highly hydrophobic active site of MAO B.(68) MAO A IC50 values ranged between 0.025 μM (14b) and 1.0 μM (14j), and among them 14d, 14e, and 14g–j were more selective than compound 1 (MAO A/KDM1A ratio of <2). 14g and 14j were the most selective ones, with a selectivity ratio higher than 10 (MAO A/KDM1A).
    Compounds 14d, 14e, and 14g−j having good biochemical activity and with an acceptable selectivity versus MAO A, were selected and further tested towards leukemia cell lines, to investigate their ability to inhibit KDM1A (see Table 2). In the first experiment, human promyelocytic leukemia NB4 cells were incubated with the inhibitors at a concentration equal to their corresponding biochemical IC50 value. NB4 cells were selected on the basis of literature data(64, 69) which indicate that the inhibition of KDM1A has a biological relevance both in human promyelocytic leukemia cell lines (NB4) and in murine primary promyelocytic blasts. After 24 h of incubation, GFI1B mRNA levels were assessed by quantitative RT-PCR to evaluate KDM1A inhibition in cells. GFI1B is a gene associated with hematopoietic differentiation; its mRNA expression increases following KDM1A down regulation (Figure S2 in Supporting Information), and importantly the gene has been demonstrated to be a direct transcriptional target of KDM1A.(70) As shown in Table 2, all the tested compounds determined at least a 4-fold increase of the mRNA expression of GFI1B, compared to cells treated with the vehicle, proving their ability to block KDM1A activity in cellular systems. Moreover, considering that KDM1A inhibition should induce differentiation of human AML cells,(40) we evaluated the effect of the compounds on the expression level of CD11b, a well-known granulocytic differentiation marker modulated by KDM1A down regulation (Figure S2 in Supporting Information). As reported in Table 2, all the tested compounds elicited, at their respective biochemical IC50, an increase of CD11b expression, which suggests granulocytic differentiation induction of the NB4 cells. Starting from experimental data,(64, 69) which indicate that the KDM1A inhibitors are of potential relevance for treatment of promyelocytic leukemia, we further investigated the cellular activity of the compounds by measuring their ability to inhibit the colony formation of murine acute myeloid leukemia blasts (originated by a murine acute promyelocytic leukemia(71)) in semisolid culture at a dose of 0.250 μM. All the selected compounds inhibited colony formation, with percentage of inhibition ranging from 84% to 57% (Table 2). To confirm that the obtained biological data specifically correlated to KDM1A inhibition, the effect of KDM1A down regulation by short hairpin RNA, both in NB4 cells and in murine promyelocytic blast, was analyzed. As reported in the Supporting Information, the effects of KDM1A silencing are in agreement with the reported biological data obtained with the inhibitors in terms of transcriptional effects on the expression of GFI1B and CD11b as well as on the reduction of colony formation in mouse acute promyelocytic blast (Supporting Information Figures S2 and S3).
    Table 2. Cellular Characterization of Selected Derivativatives 1, 14d, 14e, 14g–j, and 22
    Table a

    Fold increase mRNA expression, reported as mean values of several replicates (≥2) at the biochemical IC50, measured after 24 h of compound treatment.

    Table b

    Colonies were counted after 7 days. Maximal assay variability of 4%. Percentage of inhibition is referenced to the vehicle (DMSO) treated cells, and the data reported are the mean of several replicates plus the standard deviation (≥2).

    Table c

    Colonies were counted after 13 days. Maximal assay variability of 6%. Percentage of inhibition is referenced to the vehicle (DMSO) treated cells, and the data reported are the mean of several replicates plus the standard deviation (≥2).

    Table d

    Not determined.

    The most active compounds 14d, 14e and 14g, inhibiting the murine promyelocytic blasts at 84% and 79%, respectively, the reference compound 1 (inhibition of 73%), and 22 (inhibition of 84%) were additionally tested in a human leukemia cell line. Since the relevance of KDM1A in sustaining the oncogenic potential of MLL-AF9 leukemia stem cells has been demonstrated and reported in the literature,(40) we evaluated the anticlonogenic potential of 14d, 14e, 14g, 1, and 22 in a human leukemia cell line, characterized by MLL-AF9 translocation (THP-1). As reported in Table 2, compounds 14d, 14e, and 14g as well as 22 continued to show strong inhibitory efficacy with a percentage of inhibition of 63%, 51%, 65%, and 58%, respectively, at the fixed dose of 0.50 μM, whereas reference compound 1 unexpectedly only weakly inhibited the colony forming ability of the cells (8%). Of relevance, 14d, 14e, and 14g, similar to 22, induced a clear differentiation of THP-1 cells as demonstrated by altered morphology of the colonies and by examination of cytospin preparations of cells recovered at the end of semisolid culture (Figure 4).
    We therefore advanced through our screening funnel only those compounds with good potency in the biochemical assay, showing some level of selectivity versus MAO A and demonstrating a clear cellular efficacy in the anticlonogenic potential assay. In view of their promising overall activity in both biochemical and cellular assays 14d, 14e, and 14g were selected for preliminary pharmacokinetic assessment in mouse (Table 3) while the parent compound 1 was not included in the analysis for its very limited anticlonogenic activity observed in THP-1 cells.
    Table 3. Pharmacokinetic Parameters of 14d, 14e, and 14g e after Single iv and os Administration in CD-1 Mice
    parameter (unit)14d14e14g
    iv, 5 mg/kg
    Cmax (μM)0.739 ± 0.1263.65 ± 0.6580.383 ± 0.0367
    t1/2 (h)8.09 ± 1.021.92 ± 0.4012.3 ± 4.31
    AUC0–∞ (μM h)2.16 ± 0.5564.62 ± 1.132.45 ± 0.144
    CL (mL min–1 kg–1)94.8 ± 21.349.7 ± 12.280.7 ± 4.86
    Vz (L/kg)67.5 ± 22.18.45 ± 3.7585.7 ± 28.3
    os, 15 mg/kg
    tmax (h)12.0 ± 10.40.667 ± 0.28918.0 ± 10.4
    Cmax (μM)0.138 ± 0.05171.14 ± 0.160.0588 ± 0.00317
    AUC0–∞ (μM h)2.39 ± 0.7707.12 ± 2.040.979 ± 0.131
    F (%)4055.815.4
    The selected inhibitors were administered in single intravenously (iv) or orally (os) to CD1 mice at 5 mg/kg or 15 mg/kg, respectively. The derivatives were dissolved in 5% glucose solution containing 10% Tween 80 for the iv dose or in 5% glucose solution containing 40% PEG for the oral dose. The plasma PK parameters are summarized in Table 3. Following the iv administration, the three compounds showed medium to high clearance rates of 94.8 ± 21.3, 49.7 ± 12.2, and 80.7 ± 4.8 mL min–1 kg–1 for 14d, 14e, and 14g, respectively. The elimination half-lives were significantly longer for 14d (with ∼8 h) and for 14g (∼12 h) than for compound 14e (1.92 ± 0.40 h). Moreover, the estimated terminal volume of distribution (Vz) was high for all three compounds, which indicates an extensive tissue distribution of the molecules. In particular, 14d and 14g had Vz of 67 and 85 L/kg, respectively, much higher than 14e (Vz = 8.45).
    Compounds 14d and 14g were slowly absorbed after oral administration (tmax was 12 and 18 h for 14d and 14g, respectively), whereas 14e was taken up more rapidly (tmax of less than 1 h). Cmax and AUC0–∞ after oral administration were significantly different among the compounds. Specifically, compound 14e exhibits a Cmax of 1.14 ± 0.16 μM, which is around 20 times more than that obtained for compound 14g. The AUC0–∞ ranged from 0.979 ± 0.131 μM h (14g) to 7.12 ± 2.04 μM h (14e). The higher exposure data after oral administration of 14d and 14e compared to 14g, in terms of Cmax and AUC0–∞, and the higher oral bioavailability of compounds 14d (40%) and 14e (55.8%) compared to 14g (15.4%) prompted us to select 14d and 14e for further in vivo characterization.
    To this aim, 14d and 14e were submitted to in vivo efficacy experiment in an established murine promyelocytic leukemia model.(71, 72) For the in vivo test, one million leukemic cells were injected iv into nonirradiated 129SvEv mice. Treatment with 14d and 14e started once blast cells were detected in the recipients’ peripheral blood (10 days after cell injection). To compare the efficacy between the two selected compounds, 14d and 14e were orally administered at the fixed dose of 27 mg/kg 5 days per week for 2 weeks. The survival of mice belonging to different experimental groups was analyzed and represented by a Kaplan–Meier survival plot. No significant body weight differences among the groups of mice were observed during the treatment (data not shown), and as reported in Figure 5, both compounds elicited an increase of survival of the treated mice compared to the vehicle group. Specifically, 14d and 14e determined an increase of survival respectively of 35% and 15% with respect to the vehicle group. At this point, to investigate different schedule of compound administration for the in vivo efficacy, we considered the irreversible mechanism toward which these derivatives interact with the enzyme and we postulated that an intermittent treatment could have been desirable. 14d in fact was tested at a dose of 45 mg/kg for 3 days per week (Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday) for 2 weeks that corresponds to the same weekly cumulative dose obtained with the administration of the compound at a dose of 27 mg/kg for 5 days per week. Interestingly, the in vivo efficacy evaluated in terms of survival improved significantly (from 35% to 58%) when we followed the intermittent administration (Figure 5B). Moreover and importantly, 14d showed a significantly better in vivo efficacy in the murine promyelocytic leukemia model if compared to 22 which, once administered according to schedule/dosage reported by Oryzon,(73) was able to increase the survival of leukemic mice of 14% with respect to the vehicle group (Figure 5C).
    Furthermore, in order to correlate the observed in vivo efficacy with KDM1A inhibition, spleens of the leukemic mice treated with the vehicle and those with 14d were recovered after 3 days of treatment and cells were collected for RNA analysis. mRNA levels of GFI1B were measured by quantitative RT-PCR using specific primers and normalized against TBP mRNA. Results are presented as mRNA expression, and as illustrated in the graph (Figure 5D), both schedules determined a clear increase of GFI1B expression, although not statistically significant, supporting the ability of compound to inhibit KDM1A in vivo after oral administration.
    Encouraged by the results on the racemic mixture of compound 14d, we approached the enantioselective synthesis of 15 (1S,2R) and 16 (1R,2S) starting from the enantiomerically pure styrene epoxides. As evidenced in Table 4, compound 15 inhibited KDM1A with an IC50 of 0.084 μM and was thus 3 times more potent than the enantiomer 16 (IC50 = 0.23uM), which in turn was a weaker inhibitor with respect to the racemate (IC50 = 0.188 μM). The activity of the racemate and enantiomers versus KDM1B could be considered comparable, being in the high micromolar range. Selectivity versus MAOs remained instead almost unaltered in term of IC50 ratio for the (1S,2R) enantiomer (ratio MAO A/LSD1 = 3.5 for 15, compared to 3.9 for 14d), whereas it worsens for compound 16. An even greater difference among the enantiomers was found in the cellular assays: specifically compound 15 was more active in reducing the colony forming ability in the two used cell models and, importantly, in inducing the differentiation of THP-1 cells compared to the 1R,2S analogue 16 (Table 5 and Figure 6).
    Table 4. Biochemical Characterization of 15 and 16
    Table a

    Data are expressed as the mean of at least two determinations ± standard deviation. IC50 curves of biochemical assay are supplied as Supporting Information.

    Table 5. Cellular Characterization of 15 and 16
    Table a

    Fold increase mRNA expression, reported as mean values of several replicates (≥2) at the biochemical IC50, measured after 24 h of compound treatment.

    Table b

    Colonies were counted after 7 days. Percentage of inhibition is referenced versus the vehicle (DMSO) treated cells, and the data reported are the mean of several replicates plus the standard deviation (≥2) with a maximal assay variability of 4%.

    Table c

    Colonies were counted after 13 days. Percentage of inhibition is referenced versus the vehicle (DMSO) treated cells, and the data reported are the mean of several replicates plus the standard deviation (≥2) with a maximal assay variability of 6%.

    Compound 15 was then evaluated for its in vivo behavior. For this purpose, the pharmacokinetic profile in CD-1 mice was analyzed at the same conditions formerly described for inhibitors 14d, 14e, and 14g (Table 6). The compound exhibited a high clearance rate but somewhat lower than the racemic mixture 14d (79.7 ± 15.0 mL min–1 kg–1 for 15 over 94.8 ± 21.3 mL min–1 kg–1 for 14d). Furthermore, 15, when orally administered, exhibited a high Vz of 58.4 ± 9.78 L/kg and a half-life of more than 8 h. Although the oral bioavailability was lower than that shown by 14d (22.5% for 15 over 40% for 14d), both Cmax and AUC0–∞ were comparable (0.147 ± 0.112 and 1.66 ± 0.889 of 15 over 0.138 ± 0.0517 and 2.39 ± 0.770 of 14d).
    Table 6. Pharmacokinetic Parameters of 15 after Single iv and os Administration in CD-1 Mice
    parameter (unit)15
    iv, 5 mg/kg
    Cmax (μM)1.92 ± 0.883
    t1/2 (h)8.52 ± 1.08
    AUC0–∞ (μM h)2.29 ± 0.484
    CL (mL min–1 kg–1)79.7 ± 15.0
    Vz (L/kg)58.4 ± 9.78
    os, 15 mg/kg
    Cmax (μM)0.147 ± 0.112
    AUC0–∞ (μM h)1.66 ± 0.889
    F (%)22.5
    The single 1S,2R enantiomer 15 was tested in vivo in the murine promyelocytic leukemia model as previously described for the trans racemate 14d. 15 was dissolved (40% PEG 400 in a 5% glucose solution) and orally administered 3 days per week (Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday) for 3 weeks at the doses of 11.25 mg/kg and 22.5 mg/kg. The treatment started once blast cells were detected in the recipients’ peripheral blood (10 days after cell injection). As reported for the racemic mixture 14d, the survival of mice of the different experimental groups was analyzed and represented by a Kaplan–Meier survival plot. No significant body weight differences among the groups of mice were observed during the treatment. A significant dose dependent increase of survival was obtained, and specifically, 15 determined an increase of 35% and 62% at the dose of 11.25 and 22.50 mg/kg, respectively (Figure 7A). Remarkably the observed in vivo efficacy associated with a good tolerability profile of the compound 15 could be suggestive of its preferential activity on tumor cells with respect to normal cells. In order to correlate the observed in vivo efficacy of 15 with KDM1A inhibition, spleens of the leukemic mice treated with the vehicle or with compound at the highest tested dose of 22.5 mg/kg were recovered after 3 days of treatment and cells were collected for RNA analysis. A clear increase of GFI1B expression, although not statistically significant, was observed (Figure 7B), which supported the ability of 15 to inhibit KDM1A in vivo after oral administration.

    Conclusions

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    A series of novel and potent TCPA-derived inhibitors of KDM1A has been identified starting from the previously disclosed compound 1. Some of the compounds (14d, 14e, and 14g) demonstrated improved selectivity versus MAO A and a higher cellular activity in human THP-1 cells, showing 51–65% inhibition compared to the 8% inhibitory activity of compound 1. Pharmacokinetic studies revealed a good oral bioavailability of compounds 14d (40%) and 14e (55.8%), in both cases significantly higher than that of derivative 14g (15.4%). Compounds 14d and 14e were then studied for their in vivo antitumoral activity in a murine acute promyelocytic leukemia model. Oral treatment with compounds 14d and 14e, at the fixed dose of 27 mg/kg 5 days per week for 2 weeks, led to significant survival increase without signs of overt toxicity and with evidence of in vivo target modulation. Two enantiomers of 14d were eventually prepared and profiled, leading to the identification of the (1S,2R) eutomer 15, which showed higher potency in both biochemical and cellular assays in comparison to the (1R,2S) enantiomer 16.
    Compound 15, orally admistered in vivo in the murine promyelocytic leukemia model, was well tolerated and significantly prolonged survival time of the treated mice (35% and 62% at the doses of 11.25 and 22.50 mg/kg, respectively). Collectively, these results have supported the progress of compound 15 into preclinical development as a potential oral anticancer agent.

    Experimental section

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Chemistry. General Procedures

    Reagents and solvents used, unless stated otherwise, were of commercially available reagent grade quality and were used without further purification. Flash chromatography purifications were performed on Merck silica gel 60 (0.04–0.063 mm). Nuclear magnetic resonance spectra (1H NMR and 13C NMR) were recorded either on a Varian 500 MHz or on a Varian 400 MHz spectrometer at 300 K and are referenced in ppm (δ) relative to TMS. Coupling constants (J) are expressed in hertz (Hz). HPLC–MS experiments were performed on an Acquity UPLC apparatus, equipped with a diode array and a Micromass SQD single quadruple (Waters). Optical rotations were measured at the sodium D line, using a Krüss P3001/3002 RS automatic digital polarimeter and a 100 mm cell, and are reported as follows: concentration (c = g/100 mL), solvent. Purity was monitored at 220 nm, and the purities of the compounds used for biological tests were found to be at least 95%.

    Materials

    tert-Butyl N-[2-(4-aminophenyl)cyclopropyl]carbamate (48), tert butyl 3-chloro-4-nitrobenzoate,(66) 4-(3-furyl)benzamide,(74) benzyl N-(3-carbamoylphenyl)carbamate(75) were prepared according to procedures described in the literature. 22 was prepared according to the procedure described by Oryzon.(55)

    (1R,2R)-1-Ethyl 2-Phenylcyclopropanecarboxylate (6)

    69 mL (173 mmol) of a 2.5 M solution of n-butyllithium in hexane was added at 25 °C dropwise over 5 min to a solution of 39 g (170 mmol) of triethyl 2-phosphonoacetate in 75 mL of dry DME. The reaction mixture was stirred at rt for 5 min, and then 16.0 g (133 mmol) of (S)-styrene oxide was added in one portion. The reaction was heated at 135 °C for 60 min under microwave. The orange reaction mixture was then cooled down to rt, saturated aqueous NH4Cl was added, and the product was extracted with Et2O. The combined organic layers were dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and the solvent was removed in vacuo. The crude product was filtered on a silica gel pad, giving 21g (83%) of ethyl 2-phenylcyclopropane carboxylate as yellow oil.
    The ethyl ester was hydrolyzed according to the following procedure: 10.58 g (441.6 mmol) of LiOH in 200 mL of H2O was added to a solution of 21 g (110 mmol) of ethyl 2-phenylcyclopropanecarboxylate dissolved in 220 mL of an ethanol/THF mixture (10:1, v:v), and the solution was heated at 115 °C for 50 min under microwave irradiation. Then, the solution was concentrated, diluted with H2O, and quenched with 2 M HCl at 0 °C. The precipitate was filtered off, washed with H2O, and triturated with Et2O, providing 14.85 g (83%) of the (1R,2R) cyclopropanecarboxylic acid 6 as a white solid. 1H NMR (CDCl3) δ (ppm): 11.5 (br s, 1 H, -COOH), 7.34–7.20 (m, 3 H, aromatic protons), 7.16–7.06 (m, 2 H, aromatic protons), 2.66–2.57 (m, 1 H, -CH cyclopropane), 1.98–1.88 (m, 1 H, -CH cyclopropane), 1.73–1.61 (m, 1 H, -CHH cyclopropane), 1.47–1.37 (m, 1 H, -CHHcyclopropane). MS (ESI), m/z: 161 [M – H]−. [α]D20 −297° (c 0.753, CHCl3).
    The trans-1-ethyl-2-phenylcyclopropanecarboxylate 5 was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich.
    (1S,2S)-2-Phenylcyclopropanecarboxylic acid 7 was prepared according to the procedure described for example 6 starting from the appropriate (R)-styrene oxides and phosphonoacetates. Yield: 85%. 1H NMR (CDCl3) δ (ppm): 11.75 (br s, 1 H, -COOH), 7.35–7.08 (m, 5 H, aromatic protons), 2.67–2.56 (m, 1 H, -CH cyclopropane), 1.98–1.86 (m, 1 H, -CH cyclopropane), 1.74–1.63 (m, 1 H, -CHH cyclopropane), 1.48–1.37 (m, 1 H, -CHH cyclopropane). MS (ESI), m/z: 161 [M – H]−. [α]D20 +294° (c 0.933, CHCl3).
    Examination of ethyl esters of 5, 6, and 7 by NMR with the aid of the optically active shift reagent europium tris[3-(heptafluoropropylhydroxymethylene)-(+)-camphorate] showed 5 to be a mixture of 1 to 1 of the two enantiomers 6 and 7 to be optically pure.

    (1R,2R)-2-(4-Iodophenyl)cyclopropanecarboxylic Acid (9)

    13 g (50 mmol) of iodine, 4.5 g (21 mmol) of potassium iodate, and 7.5 mL of concentrated H2SO4 in 75 mL of H2O were added to a stirred solution of 14.7 g (90.6 mmol) of (1R,2R)-2-phenylcyclopropanecarboxylic acid in 300 mL of AcOH. The mixture was heated to reflux for about 2 h, and then the reaction was stopped by adding 700 mL of 1 M NaHSO4. The formed precipitate was filtered, dried, and the resulting solid was triturated with hexane, providing 19 g (73%) of the (1R,2R) carboxylic acid 9 as a white solid. 1H NMR (DMSO-d6) δ (ppm): 12.66–10.65 (m, 1 H, -COOH), 7.72–7.54 (m, 2 H, aromatic protons), 6.96–6.79 (m, 2 H, aromatic protons), 2.63–2.46 (m, 1 H, -CH cyclopropane), 1.97–1.80 (m, 1 H, -CH cyclopropane), 1.74–1.61 (m, 1 H, -CHH cyclopropane), 1.47–1.30 (m, 1 H, -CHHcyclopropane). MS (ESI), m/z: 287 [M – H]−.
    The following carboxylic acids were prepared according to the procedure for compound 9.

    (trans)-2-(4-Iodophenyl)cyclopropanecarboxylic Acid (8)

    Yield: 84%. 1H NMR (DMSO-d6) δ (ppm): 12.36 (br s, 1 H, -COOH), 7.65–7.55 (m, 2 H, aromatic protons), 7.06–6.93 (m, 2 H, aromatic protons), 2.40–2.28 (m, 1 H, -CH cyclopropane), 1.85–1.73 (m, 1 H, -CH cyclopropane), 1.47–1.37 (m, 1 H, -CHH cyclopropane), 1.35–1.24 (m, 1 H, -CHH cyclopropane). MS (ESI), m/z: 287 [M – H]−

    (1S,2S)-2-(4-Iodophenyl)cyclopropanecarboxylic Acid (10)

    Yield: 80%. 1H NMR (DMSO-d6) δ (ppm): 12.29 (br s, 1 H, -COOH), 7.60 (d, J = 8.3 Hz, 2 H, aromatic protons), 6.99 (d, J = 8.3 Hz, 2 H, aromatic protons), 2.41–2.27 (m, 1 H, -CH cyclopropane), 1.85–1.71 (m, 1 H, -CH cyclopropane), 1.46–1.36 (m, 1 H, -CHH cyclopropane), 1.35–1.24 (m, 1 H, -CHH cyclopropane). MS (ESI), m/z: 287 [M – H]−

    tert-Butyl N-[trans-2-(4-Iodophenyl)cyclopropyl]carbamate (11)

    7.4 g (27 mmol) of diphenylphosphoryl azide and 4.4 mL (32 mmol) of TEA were added to a solution of 7.05 g (24.5 mmol) of trans-2-(4-iodophenyl)cyclopropanecarboxylic acid in 150 mL of dry t-BuOH. After stirring at 90 °C for 20 h the solution was concentrated and the residue was partitioned between 10% aqueous Na2CO3 and Et2O. The combined organic layers were dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated. The crude product was purified by flash chromatography (hexane/EtOAc 9:1, v:v), giving 5.6 g (62%) of the tert-butyl carbamate 11 as white solid. 1H NMR (DMSO-d6) δ (ppm): 7.67–7.51 (m, 2 H, aromatic protons), 7.25 (br s, 1 H, NHCOO-t-Bu), 6.98–6.84 (m, 2 H, aromatic protons), 2.57 (br s, 1 H, -CH cyclopropane), 1.89–1.74 (m, 1 H, -CH cyclopropane), 1.37 (s, 9 H, -COO(CH3)3), 1.18–0.95 (m, 2 H, -CH2 cyclopropane). MS (ESI), m/z: 260 [MH – 100]+.
    The following carbamates were prepared according to the procedure for compound 11:

    tert-Butyl N-[(1R,2S)-2-(4-Iodophenyl)cyclopropyl]carbamate (12)

    Yield: 84%. 1H NMR (CDCl3) δ (ppm): 7.62–7.53 (m, 2 H, aromatic protons), 6.96–6.82 (m, 2 H, aromatic protons), 4.93–4.72 (m, 1 H, -NHCOOtBu), 2.76–2.60 (m, 1 H, -CH cyclopropane), 2.05–1.91 (m, 1 H, -CH cyclopropane), 1.46 (s, 9 H, -COO(CH3)3), 1.21–1.07 (m, 2 H, -CH2 cyclopropane). MS (ESI), m/z: 382 [MNa]+. [α]D20 −74° (c 0.688, MeOH).

    tert-Butyl N-[(1S,2R)-2-(4-Iodophenyl)cyclopropyl]carbamate (13)

    Yield: 81%. 1H NMR (CDCl3) δ (ppm): 7.32–7.22 (m, 2 H, aromatic protons), 7.21–7.09 (m, 3 H, aromatic protons), 4.97–4.65 (m, 1 H, -NHCOO-t-Bu), 2.85–2.64 (m, 1 H, -CH cyclopropane), 2.09–1.99 (m, 1 H-CH cyclopropane), 1.47 (s, 9 H, -COO(CH3)3), 1.23–1.10 (m, 2 H, -CH2 cyclopropane). MS (ESI), m/z: 260 [MH – 100]+. [α]D20 +89.23° (c 1.003, MeOH).

    3-(2-Oxooxazolidin-3-yl)benzamide (19e)

    A suspension of 0.56 g (2.7 mmol) of 3-(2-oxooxazolidin-3-yl)benzoic acid (18e) (Enamine Ltd.) in 15 mL of dry CH2Cl2 was treated with 0.246 mL (3.38 mmol) of thionyl chloride and 2 drops of dry DMF. After stirring at reflux for 2 h, the mixture was cooled down to rt and poured into 4 mL of an aqueous solution of NH3 (28–30% in water). After 1 h the resulting mixture was filtered off to afford a white solid that was washed with water. The aqueous phases were extracted with CH2Cl2, the combined organic layers were dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated to give 0.549 g (98%) of the benzamide 19e as a white solid. 1H NMR (DMSO-d6) δ (ppm): 8.01 (br s, 1 H, -CONHH), 7.94–7.88 (m, 1 H, aromatic proton), 7.84–7.78 (m, 1 H, aromatic proton), 7.61 (d, J = 7.8 Hz, 1 H, aromatic proton), 7.52–7.34 (m, 2 H, aromatic proton, -CONHH), 4.49–4.39 (m, 2 H, -CH2O oxazolidinone), 4.14–3.98 (m, 2 H, -CH2N oxazolidinone). MS (ESI), m/z: 207 [M + H]+.

    4-(2-Oxooxazolidin-3-yl)benzamide (19f)

    4-(2-Oxooxazolidin-3-yl)benzamide (19f) was prepared according to the procedure for compound 19e starting from 4-(2-oxo-1,3-oxazolidin-3-yl)benzoic acid (18f, Enamine Ltd.). 1H NMR (DMSO-d6) δ (ppm): 8.01–7.79 (m, 3 H, aromatic protons, -CONHH), 7.67–7.53 (m, 2 H, aromatic protons), 7.28 (br s, 1 H, -CONHH), 4.44 (t, J = 7.6 Hz, 2 H, -CH2O oxazolidinone), 4.08 (t, J = 7.6 Hz, 2 H, -CH2N oxazolidinone). MS (ESI), m/z: 207 [M + H]+.

    4-(1-Methyl-4-piperidyl)benzamide (19g)

    0.34 g (5.1 mmol) of sodium cyanoborohydride and 0.75 mL of acetic acid were added to a mixture of 0.745 g (3.63 mmol) of 4-(1-methyl-4-piperidyl)benzoic acid (18g, Fluorochem Ltd.) and 0.54 mL of 37% aqueous formaldehyde in 7.5 mL of MeOH. The mixture was stirred for about 30 min, then quenched with water and concentrated. The crude reaction intermediate was taken up with dry CH2Cl2, and 0.331 mL of (4.54 mmol) thionyl chloride and 2 drops of dry DMF were added. The solution was stirred at reflux for about 2 h, then cooled down to rt, and a further portion of 331 μL (4.538 mmol) thionyl chloride was added. Stirring at reflux was then continued for additional 2 h. For a complete conversion a third portion of 0.331 mL (4.54 mmol) of thionyl chloride was added. After further 2 h at reflux, the mixture was cooled down to rt and poured onto an ice cold solution of 15 mL of aqueous NH3 (28–30%), and the resulting mixture was partitioned between CH2Cl2 and 10% solution of Na2CO3 in water. The organic layer was dried over Na2SO4 and concentrated to give 442 mg (55% from compound 18g) of benzamide 19g as a beige solid. 1H NMR (DMSO-d6) δ (ppm): 7.80–7.58 (m, 3 H, -CONHH, aromatic protons), 7.11–6.85 (m, 3 H, -CONHH, aromatic protons), 3.27–3.15 (m, 4 H, -CH2N piperazine), 2.46–2.34 (m, 4 H, -CH2N piperazine), 2.21 (s, 3 H, -NCH3). MS (ESI): m/z: 219 [M + H]+.

    N-[4-[trans-2-Aminocyclopropyl]phenyl]-4-(4-methylpiperazin-1-yl)benzamide Dihydrochloride (14d)

    6 mg (0.03 mmol) of CuI, 220 mg (0.613 mmol) of the carbamate 11, 0.15 mg (0.67 mmol) of 4-(4-methylpiperazin-1-yl)benzamide, and 0.17 g (1.23 mmol) of K2CO3 were placed in a vial and charged with nitrogen. 5 mg (0.06 mmol) of N,N′-dimethylethane-1,2-diamine and 2 mL of dioxane were added with a syringe, and the vial was heated to 110 °C for 20 h. The resulting suspension was allowed to cool down to rt and was then filtered through a silica gel pad, eluting with 25 mL of 9:1 CH2Cl2/MeOH. The filtrate was concentrated and the residue was purified by chromatography (CH2Cl2 to CH2Cl2/MeOH 95/5) to give 223 mg (81%) of N-[trans-2-[4-[[4-(4-methylpiperazin-1-yl)benzoyl]amino]phenyl]cyclopropyl]carbamate as a white solid. 1H NMR (DMSO-d6) δ (ppm): 9.86 (s, 1 H, -CONH), 7.92–7.77 (m, 2 H, aromatic protons), 7.69–7.57 (m, 2 H, aromatic protons), 7.22 (br s, 1 H, -NHCOOtBu), 7.08–6.90 (m, 4 H, aromatic protons), 3.31–3.15 (m, 4 H, -CH2N piperazine), 2.62–2.53 (m, 1 H, -CH cyclopropane), 2.47–2.36 (m, 4 H, -CH2N piperazine), 2.22 (s, 3 H, -NCH3), 1.90–1.79 (m, 1 H, -CH cyclopropane), 1.38 (s, 9 H, -COO(CH3)3), 1.13–1.02 (m, 2 H, -CH2 cyclopropane). MS (ESI), m/z: 451 [M + H]+. Then, 2 mL of 2 M HCl in Et2O was added to a solution of 200 mg (0.44 mmol) of N-[trans-2-[4-[[4-(4-methylpiperazin-1-yl)benzoyl]amino]phenyl]cyclopropyl]carbamate in 3 mL of Et2O/MeOH (2:1, v:v) cooled down to 0 °C. After stirring at rt for 20 h the formed precipitate was filtered off and the light yellow solid washed with Et2O and dried at 40 °C under vacuum, giving 167 mg (89%) of N-[4-[trans-2-aminocyclopropyl]phenyl]-4-(4-methylpiperazin-1-yl)benzamide as its dihydrochloride salt. 1H NMR (DMSO-d6) δ (ppm): 9.97 (s, 1 H, -NH+ CH3 methyl piperazine), 9.75 (br s, 1 H, -CONH), 8.22 (br s, 3 H, -NH3+), 7.98–7.83 (m, 2 H, aromatic protons), 7.77–7.63 (m, 2 H, aromatic protons), 7.20–6.98 (m, 4 H, aromatic protons), 4.14–3.93 (m, 2 H, -CH2N piperazine), 3.60–3.45 (m, 2 H, -CH2N piperazine), 3.18–2.98 (m, 4 H, -CH2N piperazine), 2.87 (s, 3 H, -NCH3), 2.83–2.74 (m, 1 H, -CH cyclopropane), 2.27–2.17 (m, 1 H, -CH cyclopropane), 1.35–1.27 (m, 1 H, -CHH cyclopropane), 1.24–1.14 (m, 1 H, -CHH cyclopropane). MS (ESI), m/z: 351 [M + H]+.
    The following cyclopropylamines were prepared following the procedure for compound 14d starting from the carbamate 11 (14a-c, 14e-g), 12 (15) or 13 (16).

    N-[4-[trans-2-Aminocyclopropyl]phenyl]-4-(3-furyl)benzamide Hydrochloride(14a)

    Yield: 40% from 11. 1H NMR (DMSO-d6) δ (ppm): 10.21 (s, 1 H, -CONH), 8.40–8.24 (m, 4 H, -CH furan, -NH3+), 8.01–7.94 (m, 2 H, aromatic protons), 7.81–7.75 (m, 3 H, aromatic protons), 7.74–7.68 (m, 2 H, aromatic protons), 7.17–7.11 (m, 2 H, aromatic protons), 7.09–7.05 (m, 1 H, -CH furan), 2.86–2.74 (m, 1 H, -CH cyclopropane), 2.32–2.21 (m, 1 H, -CH cyclopropane), 1.40–1.29 (m, 1 H, -CHH cyclopropane), 1.25–1.11 (m, 1 H, -CHH cyclopropane). MS (ESI), m/z: 319 [M + H]+.

    Benzyl N-[3-[[4-[trans-2-Aminocyclopropyl]phenyl]carbamoyl]phenyl]carbamate Hydrochloride (14b)

    Yield: 48% from 11. 1H NMR (DMSO-d6) δ (ppm): 10.24 (s, 1 H, -NHCOO), 9.99 (s, 1 H, -CONH), 8.56 (br s, 3 H, -NH3+), 8.06–7.02 (m, 13 H, aromatic protons), 5.17 (s, 2 H, -CH2O), 2.82–2.68 (m, 1 H, -CH cyclopropane), 2.38–2.26 (m, 1 H,) -CH cyclopropane, 1.45–1.10 (m, 2 H, -CH2 cyclopropane). MS (ESI), m/z: 402 [M + H]+.

    N-[4-[(trans-2-Aminocyclopropyl]phenyl]-4-morpholinobenzamide Hydrochloride (14c)

    Yield: 21% from 11. 1H NMR (DMSO-d6) δ (ppm): 9.93 (s, 1 H, -CONH), 8.31 (br s, 3 H, -NH3+), 7.93–7.81 (m, 2 H, aromatic protons), 7.74–7.62 (m, 2 H, aromatic protons), 7.17–7.07 (m, 2 H, aromatic protons), 7.05–6.96 (m, 2 H, aromatic protons), 3.79–3.68 (m, 4 H, -CH2O morpholine), 3.29–3.19 (m, 4 H, -CH2N morpholine), 2.85–2.71 (m, 1 H, -CH cyclopropane), 2.31–2.19 (m, 1 H, -CH cyclopropane), 1.40–1.27 (m, 1 H, -CHH cyclopropane), 1.23–1.14 (m, 1 H, -CHH cyclopropane). MS (ESI), m/z: 338 [M + H]+.

    N-[4-[trans-2-Aminocyclopropyl]phenyl]-3-(2-oxooxazolidin-3-yl)benzamide Hydrochloride (14e)

    Yield: 49% from 11. 1H NMR (DMSO-d6) δ (ppm): 10.29 (s, 1 H, -CONH), 8.31 (br s, 3 H, -NH3+), 8.07–8.00 (m, 1 H, aromatic proton), 7.84–7.77 (m, 1 H, aromatic proton), 7.73–7.66 (m, 3 H, aromatic protons), 7.59–7.50 (m, 1 H, aromatic proton), 7.19–7.12 (m, 2 H, aromatic protons), 4.51–4.43 (m, 2 H, -CH2O oxazolidinone), 4.20–4.08 (m, 2 H, -CH2N oxazolidinone), 2.87–2.75 (m, 1 H, -CH cyclopropane), 2.32–2.21 (m, 1 H, -CH cyclopropane), 1.39–1.29 (m, 1 H, -CHH cyclopropane), 1.27–1.15 (m, 1 H, -CHH cyclopropane).     N-[4-[trans-2-Aminocyclopropyl]phenyl]-4-(2-oxooxazolidin-3-yl)benzamide Trifluoroacetate (14f)

    Yield: 10% from 11 and after purification of the final product by preparative HPLC. 1H NMR (DMSO-d6) δ (ppm): 10.16 (s, 1 H, -CONH), 8.12 (br s, 3 H, -NH3+), 8.02–7.96 (m, 2 H, aromatic protons), 7.74–7.66 (m, 4 H, aromatic protons), 7.18–7.08 (m, 2 H, aromatic protons), 4.55–4.40 (m, 2 H, -CH2O oxazolidinone), 4.20–4.02 (m, 2 H, -CH2N oxazolidinone), 2.85–2.74 (m, 1 H, -CH cyclopropane), 2.31–2.15 (m, 1 H, -CHH cyclopropane), 1.36–1.13 (m, 2 H, -CHH cyclopropane).     N-[4-[trans-2-Aminocyclopropyl]phenyl]-4-(1-methyl-4-piperidyl)benzamide Trifluoroacetate (14g)

    Yield: 10% from 11 and after purification of the final product by preparative HPLC. 1H NMR (DMSO-d6) δ (ppm): 10.17 (s, 1 H, -CONH), 9.39 (br s, 1 H, -NH+CH3 piperidine), 8.23 (br s, 3 H, -NH3+), 7.98–7.87 (m, 2 H, aromatic protons), 7.73–7.61 (m, 2 H, aromatic protons), 7.48–7.31 (m, 2 H, aromatic protons), 7.19–7.09 (m, 2 H, aromatic protons), 3.61–3.45 (m, 2 H, -CH2N piperidine), 3.14–2.99 (m, 2 H, -CH2N piperidine), 2.94–2.75 (m, 5 H, -NCH3, -CH piperidine, -CH cyclopropane), 2.30–2.19 (m, 1 H, -CH cyclopropane), 2.12–1.98 (m, 2 H, -CH2 piperidine), 1.93–1.78 (m, 2 H, -CH2 piperidine), 1.36–1.28 (m, 1 H, -CHH cyclopropane), 1.23–1.14 (m, 1 H, -CHH cyclopropane). MS (ESI), m/z: 350 [M + H]+.

    N-[4-[(1S,2R)-2-Aminocyclopropyl]phenyl]-4-(4-methylpiperazin-1-yl)benzamide Dihydrochloride (15)

    1H NMR (DMSO-d6) δ (ppm): 10.85 (br. s., 1 H, -NH+CH3 piperazine), 10.00 (s, 1 H, -CONH), 8.44 (br s, 3 H, -NH3+), 7.95–7.85 (m, 2 H, aromatic protons), 7.74–7.65 (m, 2 H, aromatic protons), 7.10 (dd, J = 9.0, 12.5 Hz, 4 H, aromatic protons), 4.07–3.96 (m, 2 H, -CH2N piperazine), 3.54–3.43 (m, 2 H, -CH2N piperazine), 3.25–3.07 (m, 4 H, -CH2N piperazine), 2.86–2.70 (m, 4 H, -NCH3, -CH cyclopropane), 2.33–2.23 (m, 1 H, -CH cyclopropane), 1.41–1.30 (m, 1 H, -CHH cyclopropane), 1.22–1.11 (m, 1 H, -CHH cyclopropane). MS (ESI), m/z: 351 [M + H]+. [α]D20 −46.48° (c 0.00236, DMSO).

    N-[4-[(1R,2S)-2-Aminocyclopropyl]phenyl]-4-(4-methylpiperazin-1-yl)benzamide Dihydrochloride (16)

    1H NMR (DMSO-d6) δ (ppm): 11.00 (br s, 1 H, -NH+CH3 piperazine), 10.01 (s, 1 H, -CONH), 8.48 (br. s, 3 H, -NH3+), 7.97–7.85 (m, 2 H, aromatic protons), 7.74–7.63 (m, 2 H, aromatic protons), 7.17–7.01 (m, 4 H, aromatic protons), 4.08–3.95 (m, 2 H, -CH2N piperazine), 3.54–3.42 (m, 2 H, -CH2N piperazine), 3.27–3.03 (m, 4 H, -CH2N piperazine), 2.87–2.67 (m, 4 H, -NCH3, -CH cyclopropane), 2.36–2.23 (m, 1 H, -CH cyclopropane), 1.43–1.30 (m, 1 H, -CHH cyclopropane), 1.22–1.09 (m, 1 H, -CHH cyclopropane). MS (ESI), m/z: 351 [M + H]+. [α]D20 +41.21° (c 0.00236, DMSO).

    tert-Butyl 4-(4-Methylpiperazin-1-yl)-3-nitrobenzoate (19j)

    A suspension of 2.0 g (7.8 mmol) tert butyl 4-chloro-3-nitrobenzoate, 3.22 g (23.3 mmol) of dry K2CO3), and 2.58 mL (23.3 mmol) of N-methylpiperazine was stirred in 10 mL of dry DMF at 90 °C for 5 h in a sealed tube. Then, the reaction mixture was quenched with water and extracted with EtOAc. The combined organic phases were washed with brine, dried over Na2SO4, concentrated and the residue was purified on silica gel (eluent, EtOAc) and recrystallized from toluene to obtain 2.3 g (92%) of intermediate 19j as a yellow solid. 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz) δ 8.37 (s, 1H, aromatic proton), 8.03–8.06 (d, 1H, aromatic proton), 7.07–7.10 (d, 1H, aromatic proton), 3.20 (t, 4H, -PhN(CH2)2), 2.58 (t, 4H, -CH3N(CH2)2), 2.38 (s, 3H, -NCH3), 1.61 (s, 9H, -COOC(CH3)3) ppm. 13C NMR (CDCl3, 100 MHz) δ 164.9, 147.8, 137.2, 135.8, 134.0, 119.3, 115.8, 82.6, 57.7 (2C), 51.9 (2C), 47.0, 28.9 (3C) ppm. MS (EI) m/z: 321.17 [M]+. Mp 138–140 °C. The following tert-butyl benzoates were prepared starting from tert butyl 3-chloro-4-nitrobenzoate and morpholine (19i) or tert butyl 4-chloro-3-nitrobenzoate and piperidine (19k) or morpholine (19h) according to the procedure for intermediate 19j.

    tert-Butyl 4-Morpholino-3-nitrobenzoate (19h)

    Yield: 85%. 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz) δ 8.38–8.39 (d, 1H, aromatic proton), 8.06–8.08 (dd, 1H, aromatic proton), 7.08–7.10 (d, 1H, aromatic proton), 3.87 (t, 4H, -O(CH2)2), 3.16 (t, 4H, -N(CH2)2), 1.61 (s, 9H, -COOC(CH3)3) ppm. 13C NMR (CDCl3, 100 MHz) δ 165.1, 148.7, 134.9, 134.8, 131.0, 122.5, 120.1, 81.5, 66.9 (2C), 51.3 (2C), 28.2 (3C) ppm. MS (EI) m/z: 308.14 [M]+. Mp 149–151 °C.

    tert-Butyl 3-Morpholino-4-nitrobenzoate (19i)

    Yield: 87%. 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz) δ 7.79 (d, 1H, aromatic proton), 7.76 (d, 1H, aromatic proton), 7.65–7.67 (dd, 1H, aromatic proton), 3.86 (t, 4H, -O(CH2)2), 3.10 (t, 4H, -N(CH2)2), 1.63 (s, 9H, -COOC(CH3)3) ppm. 13C NMR (CDCl3, 100 MHz) δ 165.1, 142.8, 138.4, 130.9, 127.1, 121.7, 120.1, 81.5, 66.7 (2C), 51.4 (2C), 28.2 (3C) ppm. MS (EI) m/z: 308.14 [M]+. Mp 57–60 °C.

    tert-Butyl 4-(1-Piperidyl)-3-nitrobenzoate (19k)

    Yield: 88%. 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz) δ 8.38 (d, 1H, aromatic proton), 7.98–8.00 (dd, 1H, aromatic proton), 7.07–7.08 (d, 1H, aromatic proton), 2.89 (t, 4H, -N(CH2)2), 1.62–1.64 (m, 6H, piperidine protons), 1.54 (s, 9H, -COOC(CH3)3) ppm. 13C NMR (CDCl3, 100 MHz) δ 165.1, 148.7, 134.9, 134.8, 131.0, 122.5, 120.1, 81.5, 52.6 (2C), 28.2 (3C), 26.1 (2C), 24.0 ppm. MS (EI) m/z: 306.16 [M]+. Mp 144–146 °C.

    tert-Butyl 3-Amino-4-(4-methylpiperazin-1-yl)benzoate (20j)

    A suspension of 0.80 g (2.5 mmol) of the tert-butyl nitrobenzoate 19j in 30 mL of MeOH and 0.13 g (0.12 mmol) of 10% palladium on carbon was placed in a Parr apparatus and was hydrogenated at 50 psi and 25 °C for 5 h. The palladium was then filtered off and the MeOH was evaporated to afford an oily residue that was first purified on silica gel (eluent, CHCl3/MeOH, 10:1, v:v) and then recrystallized from cyclohexane to provide 0.29 g (65%) of the tert-butyl 4-aminobenzoate 20j as a yellow solid. 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz) δ 7.41–7.43 (dd, 1H, aromatic proton), 7.36 (d, 1H, aromatic proton), 6.99–7.00 (d, 1H, aromatic proton), 3.96 (s, 2H, Ph(NH2)), 2.98 (t, 4H, -PhN(CH2)2), 2.61 (t, 4H, -CH3N(CH2)2), 2.38 (s, 3H, -N(CH3)), 1.58 (s, 9H,-COOC(CH3)3) ppm. 13C NMR (CDCl3, 100 MHz) δ 165.1, 141.5, 137.7, 124.5 (2C), 119.9, 117.3, 81.5, 53.2 (2C), 50.0 (2C), 44.7, 28.2 (3C) ppm. MS (EI) m/z: 291.19 [M]+. Mp 114–116 °C.
    The following tert-butyl benzoates were prepared starting from the tert-butyl benzoate 19h, 19i, or 19k according to the procedure for intermediate 20j.

    tert-Butyl 4-Morpholino-3-aminobenzoate (20h)

    Yield: 73%. 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz) δ 7.42–7.45 (d, 1H, aromatic proton), 7.38 (s, 1H, aromatic proton), 6.98–7.02 (d, 1H, aromatic proton), 4.0 (br s, 2H, -PhNH2), 3.88 (t, 4H, -O(CH2)2), 2.98 (t, 4H, -N(CH2)2), 1.61 (s, 9H, -COOC(CH3)3) ppm. 13C NMR (CDCl3, 100 MHz) δ 164.7, 142.2, 134.4, 120.7, 120.5, 115.4, 115.0, 81.7, 66.3 (2C), 53.4 (2C), 28.8 (3C) ppm. MS (EI) m/z: 278.16 [M]+. Mp 126–128 °C.

    tert-Butyl 3-Morpholino-4-aminobenzoate (20i)

    Yield: 84%. 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz) δ 7.68 (d, 1H, aromatic proton), 7.63 (dd, 1H, aromatic proton), 6.69–6.71 (d, 2H, aromatic proton), 4.39 (br s, 2H, -PhNH2), 3.87 (t, 4H, -O(CH2)2), 2.93(t, 4H, -N(CH2)2), 1.59 (s, 9H, -COOC(CH3)3) ppm. 13C NMR (CDCl3, 100 MHz) δ 165.1, 140.1, 139.2, 123.8, 123.3, 119.2, 115.4, 81.5, 66.6 (2C), 50.5 (2C), 28.2 (3C) ppm. MS (EI) m/z: 278.16. Mp 136–138 °C.

    tert-Butyl 4-(1-Piperidyl)-3-aminobenzoate (20k)

    Yield: 67%. 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz) δ 7.11–7.13 (dd, 1H, aromatic proton), 6.81 (d, 1H, aromatic proton), 6.58–6.60 (d, 1H, aromatic proton), 4.35 (s, 2H, -NH2), 2.96 (t, 4H, piperidine proton), 1.77 (m, 4H, piperidine proton), 1.63 (m, 2H, piperidine proton), 1.54 (s, 9H, -COOC(CH3)3) ppm. 13C NMR (CDCl3, 100 MHz) δ 165.1, 141.5, 137.7, 124.6, 124.5, 120.0, 117.3, 81.5, 51.0 (2C), 28.2 (3C), 25.6 (2C), 24.0 ppm. MS (EI) m/z: 276.18 [M]+. Mp 115–117 °C.

    tert-Butyl 3-(Benzyloxycarbonylamino)-4-(4-methylpiperazin-1-yl)benzoate (21j)

    Benzyl chloroformate (2.1 mmol, 0.3 mL) was slowly added at 0 °C to a solution of 0.50 g (1.72 mmol) of tert-butyl 4-amino-3-(4-methylpiperazin-1-yl)benzoate (20j) in 10 mL of THF and 0.29 mL (2.1 mmol) of TEA. After stirring at rt for 1.5 h the solution was then quenched with water (20 mL) and extracted with CH2Cl2 (3 × 20 mL). The organic phases were washed with brine, dried over Na2SO4, and concentrated to afford a residue that was purified on silica gel (eluent EtOAc/CHCl3, 1:1, v:v) providing 0.53 g (65%) of the tert-butyl benzoate 21j. 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz) δ 8.69 (br s, 1H, -PhNHCOO), 7.69–7.71 (m, 2H, aromatic proton), 7.37–7.47 (m, 5H, -CH2Ph), 7.15–7.17 (d, 1H, aromatic proton), 5.28 (s, 2H, -COOCH2Ph), 2.92 (t, 4H, -PhN(CH2)2), 2.61 (t, 4H, CH3N(CH2)2), 2.20 (s, 3H, -N(CH3)), 1.60 ((s, 9H, -COOC(CH3)3) ppm. 13C NMR (CDCl3, 100 MHz) δ 165.1, 155.9, 144.2, 136.3, 130.3, 128.3 (2C), 128.1 (2C), 127.9, 124.4, 124.0, 120.9, 118.1, 81.5, 67.0, 53.2 (2C), 50.0 (2C), 44.7, 28.2 (3C) ppm. MS (EI) m/z: 425.23 [M]+.
    The following tert-butyl benzoates were prepared starting from the tert butyl benzoate 20h, 20i, or 20k according to the procedure for intermediate 21j.

    tert-Butyl 4-Morpholino-3-(benzyloxycarbonylamino)benzoate (21h)

    Yield: 71%. 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz) δ 8.71 (br s, 1H, -PhNHCOO), 7.71–7.73 (m, 2H, aromatic proton), 7.38–7.47 (m, 5H, -CH2Ph), 7.15–7.17 (d, 1H, aromatic proton), 5.27 (s, 2H, -COOCH2Ph), 3.88 (t, 4H, -O(CH2)2), 2.89 (t, 4H, -N(CH2)2), 1.60 (s, 9H, -COOC(CH3)3) ppm. 13C NMR (CDCl3, 100 MHz) δ 165.1, 155.9, 144.2, 136.3, 130.3, 128.3 (2C), 128.1 (2C), 128.0, 124.4, 124.0, 120.9, 118.1, 81.5, 67.0, 66.6 (2C), 50.5 (2C), 28.2 (3C) ppm. MS (EI) m/z: 425.23 [M]+.

    tert-Butyl 3-Morpholino-4-(benzyloxycarbonylamino)benzoate (21i)

    Yield: 73%. 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz) δ 8.20 (d, 1H, aromatic proton), 8.15 (br s, 1H, -Ph(NH)COO), 7.81–7.83 (m, 2H, aromatic protons), 7.38–7.45 (m, 5H, -CH2(Ph)), 5.26 (s, 2H, -COO(CH2)Ph), 3.88 (t, 4H, -O(CH2)2), 2.89 (t, 4H, -N(CH2)2), 1.61 (s, 9H, -COOC(CH3)3)ppm. 13C NMR (CDCl3, 100 MHz) δ 165.1, 155.9, 138.8, 136.3, 128.8, 128.3 (2C), 128.1 (2C), 127.9, 125.1, 122.4, 120.8, 118.6, 81.5, 67.0, 66.6 (2C), 50.5 (2C), 28.2 (3C) ppm. MS (EI) m/z: 425.23 [M]+.

    tert-Butyl 4-(1-Piperidyl)-3-(benzyloxycarbonylamino)benzoate (21k)

    Yield: 68%. 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz) δ 8.08–8.11 (dd, 1H, aromatic proton), 7.86–7.87 (d, 1H, aromatic proton), 7.33 (m, 5H, aromatic protons), 7.03 (d, 1H, aromatic proton), 6.80 (s, 1H, -CONHPh), 5.10 (s, 2H, -COOCH2Ph), 2.96 (t, 4H, piperidine protons), 1.77 (m, 4H, piperidine protons), 1.63 (m, 2H, piperidine protons), 1.54 (s, 9H, -COOC(CH3)3) ppm. 13C NMR (CDCl3, 100 MHz) δ 165.1, 155.8, 144.2, 136.3, 130.3, 128.3 (2C), 128.1 (2C), 127.9, 124.4, 124.0, 120.9, 118.1, 81.5, 67.0, 51.0 (2C), 28.2 (3C), 25.6 (2C), 23.9 ppm. MS (EI) m/z: 410.22 [M]+.

    3-(Benzyloxycarbonylamino)-4-(4-methylpiperazin-1-yl)benzoic Acid (18j)

    A solution of 0.20 g (0.47 mmol) of tert-butyl benzoate 21j and 0.72 mL (9.4 mmol) of TFA in 5 mL of dry CH2Cl2 was stirred at rt overnight. The solvent was then removed and the resulting solid was first triturated with 10 mL of Et2O and then crystallized from acetonitrile to give 0.13 g (76%) of the benzoic acid 18j as a colorless solid. 1H NMR (DMSO-d6, 400 MHz) δ 12.84 (br s, 1H, -COOH), 9.85 (br s, 1H, -PhNHCOO), 8.36 (s, 1H, aromatic proton), 7.66–7.68 (d, 1H, aromatic proton), 7.40–7.46 (m, 3H, aromatic protons), 7.36–7.38 (d, 2H, aromatic protons), 7.22–7.25 (d, 1H, aromatic proton), 5.22 (s, 2H, -COOCH2Ph), 3.20 (t, 4H, -PhN(CH2)2), 3.08 (t, 4H, CH3N(CH2)2), 2.86 (s, 3H, -N(CH3)) ppm. 13C NMR (DMSO- d6, 100 MHz) δ 167.6, 155.8, 145.2, 136.3, 129.3, 128.3 (2C), 128.1 (2C), 127.9, 125.2, 125.1, 119.7, 118.2, 67.0, 53.2 (2C), 50.0 (2C), 44.7 ppm. MS (EI) m/z: 369.17 [M]+. Mp 205–207 °C.
    The following tert-butyl benzoates were prepared starting from the tert butyl benzoate 21h, 21i, or 21k according to the procedure for intermediate 18j.

    4-Morpholino-3-(benzyloxycarbonylamino)benzoic Acid (18h)

    Yield: 83%. 1H NMR (DMSO-d6, 400 MHz) δ 12.88 (br s, 1H, -COOH), 9.72 (br s, 1H, -NH+), 8.76 (br s, 1H, -NHCOOCH2Ph), 8.04–8.06 (d, 1H, aromatic proton), 7.75–7.77 (d, 1H, aromatic proton), 7.70 (s, 1H, aromatic proton), 7.36–7.47 (m, 5H, -CH2Ph), 5.23 (s, 2H, -NHCOOCH2Ph), 3.46–3.48 (t, 4H, -PhN(CH2)2), 2.99–3.12 (m, 4H, -CH3N(CH2)2), 2.87 (s, 3H, -NCH3) ppm. 13C NMR (DMSO-d6, 400 MHz) δ 166.8, 154.1, 142.7, 136.3, 128.8 (2C), 127.5, 127.3 (2C), 126.2, 124.6, 122.7, 120.4, 112.5, 66.9, 57.2 (2C), 52.4 (2C), 46.7 ppm. MS (EI) m/z: 356.14 [M]+. Mp 234–236 °C.

    3-Morpholino-4-(benzyloxycarbonylamino)benzoic Acid (18i)

    Yield: 88%. 1H NMR (DMSO-d6, 400 MHz) δ 12.81 (br s, 1H, -COOH), 8.61 (s, 1H, PhNHCOO), 7.96–7.98 (d, 1H, aromatic proton), 7.71–7.73 (m, 2H, aromatic proton), 7.33–7.46 (m, 5H, -CH2Ph), 5.22 (s, 2H, -COOCH2Ph), 3.77 (t, 4H, -O(CH2)2), 2.81 (t, 4H, -N(CH2)2) ppm. 13C NMR (DMSO-d6, 100 MHz) δ 167.6, 155.8, 138.7, 136.3, 130.9, 128.3 (2C), 128.1 (2C), 127.9, 126.7, 122.14, 121.0, 116.2, 67.0, 66.6 (2C), 50.5 (2C) ppm. MS (EI) m/z: 369.16 [M]+. Mp 218–220 °C.

    4-(1-Piperidyl)-3-(benzyloxycarbonylamino)benzoic Acid (18k)

    Yield: 86%. 1H NMR (DMSO-d6, 400 MHz) δ 12.99 (s, 1 H, -COOH), 9.88 (s, 1H, -CONHPh), 8.38 (d, 1H, aromatic proton), 8.15–8.17 (dd,1H, aromatic proton), 7.40–7.41 (d, 1H, aromatic proton), 7.29–7.36 (m, 5H, aromatic protons), 4.87 (s, 2H, -COOCH2Ph), 2.99 (t, 4H, piperidine protons), 1.77 (m, 4H, piperidine protons), 1.59 (m, 2H, piperidine protons) ppm. 13C NMR (DMSO-d6, 100 MHz) δ 167.6, 155.9, 145.2, 136.3, 129.3, 128.3 (2C), 128.1 (2C), 127.9, 125.2, 125.1, 119.7, 118.2, 67.0, 51.0 (2C), 25.6 (2C), 24.0 ppm. MS (EI) m/z: 354.15 [M]+. Mp 214–216 °C.

    Benzyl N-[5-[[4-[trans-2-Aminocyclopropyl]phenyl]carbamoyl]-2-(4-methylpiperazin-1-yl)phenyl]carbamate Dihydrochloride (14j)

    0.15 mL (1.08 mmol) of TEA and 0.17 g (0.32 mmol) of PyBop were added to a solution of 0.10 g (0.27 mmol) of the benzoic acid 18j in dry DMF under nitrogen atmosphere, and the resulting mixture was stirred at rt for 45 min. 0.067 g (2.71 mmol) of tert-butyl N-[trans-2-(4-aminophenyl)cyclopropyl]carbamate (17)(48) was added under N2 atmosphere and the reaction was continued overnight, then quenched with water (20 mL), and the product was extracted with CH2Cl2 (3 × 20 mL). The combined organic phases were washed with brine, dried over Na2SO4, and concentrated to furnish a residue that was purified by chromatography on silica gel (eluent, EtOAc/CHCl3, 1:1, v:v) giving benzyl N-[5-[[4-[trans-2-(tert-butoxycarbonylamino)cyclopropyl]phenyl]carbamoyl]-2-(4-methylpiperazin-1-yl)phenyl]carbamate. Yield: 68%. 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz) δ 11.12 (br s, 1H, -NH+), 10.27 (br s, 1H, -PhCONH), 8.74 (br s, 1H, -NHCOOCH2Ph), 8.01–8.03 (d, 1H, aromatic proton), 7.79–7.86 (m, 2H, aromatic protons), 7.70–7.72 (d, 2H, aromatic protons), 7.34–7.48 (m, 5H, aromatic protons), 7.13–7.16 (d, 2H, aromatic protons), 5.23 (s, 2H, -NHCOOCH2Ph), 4.89 (br s, 1H, -NHCOOC(CH3)3), 3.32–3.38 (m, 4H, -NCH3 and -PhCH), 3.15 (m, 4H, -PhN(CH2)2), 2.80 (m, 4H, -CH3N(CH2)2), 2.31 (m, 1H, -CHNH2), 1.50 (s, 9H, -C(CH3)3), 1.37 (m, 1H, -CHH cyclopropane), 1.18 (m, 1H, -CHH cyclopropane) ppm. 13C NMR (CDCl3, 100 MHz) δ 164.9, 155.8, 153.7, 143.3, 137.5, 136.4, 134.5, 130.8, 129.3 (2C), 127.9, 127.6 (2C), 125.3 (2C), 124.5, 122.6, 121.6 (2C), 119.5, 110.3, 79.8, 66.5, 57.4 (2C), 52.3 (2C), 46.8, 32.7, 28.6 (3C), 23.1, 14.5 ppm. MS (EI) m/z: 599.31 [M]+. MS (EI) m/z: 599.31 [M]+. Then, the Boc protection group was removed by stirring a solution of 0.06 g (0.1 mmol) of benzyl N-[5-[[4-[trans-2-(tert-butoxycarbonylamino)cyclopropyl]phenyl]carbamoyl]-2-(4-methylpiperazin-1-yl)phenyl]carbamate in tetrahydrofuran (5 mL), and 0.5 mL of 4 M HCl in 1,4-dioxane was stirred at rt overnight. The formed solid was then filtered off and washed with Et2O (3 × 5 mL) to afford the cyclopropylamine 14j as a colorless solid (79%). 1H NMR (DMSO-d6, 400 MHz) δ 11.12 (br s, 1H, -NH+), 10.27 (br s, 1H, -PhCONH), 8.74 (br s, 1H, -NHCOOCH2Ph), 8.56 (br s, 3H, -NH3+), 8.01–8.03 (d, 1H, aromatic proton), 7.79–7.86 (m, 2H, aromatic protons), 7.70–7.72 (d, 2H, aromatic protons), 7.30–7.48 (m, 5H, aromatic protons), 7.15–7.18 (d, 2H, aromatic protons), 5.23 (s, 2H, -NHCOOCH2Ph), 3.33 (s, 3H, -NCH3), 3.15 (m, 4H, -PhN(CH2)2), 2.83 (t, 4H, -CH3N(CH2)2), 2.34 (m, 1H, -CHNH2), 1.39 (m, 1H, -CHH cyclopropane), 1.20 (m, 1H, CHH cyclopropane) ppm. 13C NMR (DMSO-d6, 100 MHz) δ 164.8, 153.8, 146.4, 137.3, 136.3, 134.5, 129.0 (2C), 127.9, 127.4 (2C), 125.9, 125.5 (2C), 123.9, 121.3 (2C), 121.0, 118.2, 114.7, 66.8, 57.3 (2C), 52.1 (2C), 46.7, 34.4, 25.6, 17.3 ppm. MS (ESI) m/z: 500 ([M + H]+).
    The following tert-butyl benzoates were prepared starting from the tert butyl benzoate 18h, 18i, or 18k according to the procedure for compound 14j.

    Benzyl N-[5-[[4-[trans-2-Aminocyclopropyl]phenyl]carbamoyl]-2-morpholinophenyl]carbamate Hydrochloride (14h)

    Yield: 77%. 1H NMR (DMSO-d6, 400 MHz) δ 11.13 (br s, 1H, -NH+), 10.30 (br s, 1H, -PhCONH), 8.75 (br s, 1H, -NHCOOCH2Ph), 8.58 (br s, 3H, -NH3+), 8.03–8.05 (d, 1H, aromatic proton), 7.79–7.86 (m, 2H, aromatic protons), 7.71–7.73 (d, 2H, aromatic protons), 7.32–7.46 (m, 5H, aromatic protons), 7.15–7.18 (d, 2H, aromatic protons), 5.27 (s, 2H, -NHCOOCH2Ph), 3.88 (m, 4H, -O(CH2)2), 2.89 (t, 4H, -N(CH2)2), 2.33 (m, 1H, -CHNH2), 1.38 (m, 1H, -CHH cyclopropane), 1.21 (m, 1H, -CHH cyclopropane) ppm. 13C NMR (DMSO-d6, 100 MHz) δ 166.0, 155.8, 144.7, 140.3, 136.4, 136.3, 128.9, 128.6, 128.3 (2C), 128.1 (2C), 127.9, 126.3 (2C), 124.7, 122.4 (2C), 120.2, 117.5, 67.0, 66.6 (2C), 50.5 (2C), 36.7, 26.9, 19.5 ppm. MS (ESI) m/z: 487 ([M + H]+). Yield: 77%.

    Benzyl N-[4-[[4-[trans-2-Aminocyclopropyl]phenyl]carbamoyl]-2-morpholinophenyl]carbamate Hydrochloride (14i)

    Yield: 78%. 1H NMR (DMSO-d6, 400 MHz) δ 10.15 (br s, 1H, -PhCONH), 8.61 (br s, 1H, -NHCOOCH2Ph), 8.47 (br s, 3H, -NH3+), 7.94–8.02 (m, 2H, aromatic protons), 7.74–7.83 (m, 3H, aromatic protons), 7.69–7.71 (d, 1H, aromatic proton), 7.31–7.46 (m, 6H, aromatic protons), 7.14–7.16 (d, 1H, aromatic proton), 5.22 (s, 2H, -NHCOOCH2Ph), 3.79 (m, 4H, -O(CH2)2), 2.88 (t, 4H, -N(CH2)2), 2.33 (m, 1H, -CHNH2), 1.38 (m, 1H, -CHH cyclopropane), 1.22 (m, 1H, -CHH cyclopropane) ppm. 13C NMR (DMSO-d6, 100 MHz) δ 164.8, 153.8, 143.1, 137.3, 136.0, 134.3, 130.8, 128.8 (2C), 127.6, 127.3 (2C), 125.3 (2C), 124.2, 122.7, 121.1 (2C), 119.1, 110.2, 66.9, 66.5 (2C), 53.3 (2C), 34.4, 25.6, 17.4 ppm. MS (EI) m/z: 486.23 [M]+.

    Benzyl N-[5-[[4-[trans-2-Aminocyclopropyl]phenyl]carbamoyl]-2-(1-piperidyl)phenyl]carbamate Hydrochloride (14k)

    Yield: 86%. 1H NMR (DMSO-d6, 400 MHz) δ 11.12 (br s, 1H, -NH+), 10.30 (br s, 1H, -PhCONH), 8.74 (br s, 1H, -NHCOOCH2Ph), 8.56 (br s, 3H, -NH3+), 8.02–8.04 (d, 1H, aromatic proton), 7.79–7.86 (m, 2H, aromatic protons), 7.68–7.70 (d, 2H, aromatic protons), 7.32–7.46 (m, 5H, aromatic protons), 7.14–7.17 (d, 2H, aromatic protons), 5.23 (s, 2H, -NHCOOCH2Ph), 3.32–3.36 (m, 1H, -PhCH), 3.0 (t, 4H, --N(CH2)2), 2.34 (m, 1H, -CHNH2), 1.52–1.59 (m, 6H, piperidine protons), 1.39 (m, 1H, -CHH cyclopropane), 1.20 (m, 1H, -CHH cyclopropane) ppm. 13C NMR (DMSO-d6, 100 MHz) δ 164.8, 153.9, 146.5, 137.3, 136.2, 134.5, 128.9 (2C), 127.7, 127.5 (2C), 125.9, 125.4 (2C), 124.0, 121.3 (2C), 120.8, 118.5, 114.8, 66.8, 54.7 (2C), 34.4, 25.7, 25.5 (2C), 24.5, 17.2 ppm. MS (ESI) m/z: 485 ([M + H]+).

    Biological Evaluation. KDM1A (LSD1) Enzyme Inhibition Assay

    The KDM1A (LSD1) enzyme inhibition assay was performed as described previously.(69)

    Bioluminescent-Coupled Assay for Monoamine Oxidases (MAO Glo Assay)

    The MAO Glo assay from Promega (catalog V1402, Promega, Madison, WI) was performed as described previously.(69)

    Cell Studies (Transcriptional Assay)

    The transcriptional assay was performed as described previously.(69)

    Cell Studies (Clonogenic Assay)

    Murine Acute Myeloid Leukemia Blast

    Murine acute myeloid leukemia blasts were recovered from spleen of acute promyelocytic leukemic mice sacrificed once that the spleen was completely blast infiltrated. Specifically, the model was previously characterized and obtained by injection in 129sv mice of lineage-depleted cells from 129sv mice purified and transduced with PML-RARA-expressing retroviral vector.(52) One million of leukemic blast cells (from 129sv mice) injected intravenously into nonirradiated syngenic recipients are able to induce leukemia development leading to mice death 21 days after blast injection.
    For the clonogenic assay, murine acute myeloid leukemic cells (20 000 cells) originated from spleen of leukemic mice were seeded in duplicate in methylcellulose medium (MethoCult GF M3434, Stem Cell Technology, Vancouver, BC, Canada) in the presence of the compounds at a fixed concentration of 0.25 μM. After 7 days, colonies were counted. Percentage of inhibition is referenced versus the vehicle (DMSO) treated cells.

    THP-1 Cells

    Human THP-1 cells were grown in RPMI supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum, 2 mM l-glutamine, and antibiotics and maintained in a humidified tissue culture incubator at 37 °C in 5% CO2.
    For the clonogenic assay, THP-1 cells were plated at a density of 250 cells/plate and cultured with drugs at 0.5 μM in MethoCult H4435 Enriched (StemCell Technologies, Vancouver, BC) according with the manufacturer instructions for 13 days. After this time, colonies were counted. Percentage of inhibition is referenced versus the vehicle (DMSO) treated cells.

    Retroviral Constructs and Production of Retroviruses

    shRNA constructs were prepared in the MSCV-based pLMP retroviral vector. The hairpins used in the study were #12 and #13 (scramble ShRNAs) and 1A#3 and 1A#5 (shRNAs against KDM1A):
    #12, AGTACGCGAAGAATACTATCGA
    #13, AGTACGTTCAGAATATCATCGAT
    1A#3, AAGTGATACTGTGCTTGTCCAC
    1A#5, ATCTCAGAAGATGAGTATTATT
    Supernatants from transfected Phoenix packaging cells were collected at 48 and 72 h after transfection and immediately used for infections.

    Retroviral Transduction of NB4 and Murine Myeloid Cells

    For NB4 cells infection, cells were diluted in retroviral supernatants added with 8 μg/mL polybrene and seeded at 106 cells/well in 24-well plates. Spin infection was performed for 2 consecutive days (2 infections per day) at 1800 rpm for 45 min. Puromycin selection (3μg/mL) started 24 h after the last cycle of infection. Assays were carried out 8 days after beginning of infection.
    For murine myeloid cells infection, cells were seeded at a density of 2 × 106 cells/well onto RetroNectin-coated (Takara Bio Inc., Japan) nontreated 24-well plates (Corning Costar). Spin infection was performed as for NB4 cells 24 h after the last cycle of infection cells were seeded as for clonogenic assay in the presence of 3 μg/mL of puromycin. After 7 days colonies were pooled and 20 000 cells replated in the absence of puromycin. Assays were carried out 7 days later.

    Immunoblots and Antibodies

    Whole cell extracts were obtained by lysis in SDS buffer (50 mM Tris-HCl, 10% glycerol, 2% SDS). Proteins were separated by SDS–PAGE, blotted onto PVDF membrane and probed with the indicated antibodies. The antibodies used in the study were anti-LSD1(KDM1A) (no. 2139, Cell Signaling), anti-KDM1B (Sigma HPA031269), and anti-HDAC1 (ab7028),

    In Vivo Activity

    The in vivo activity was conducted on a mouse model as described by Minucci et al.(52) The model is characterized by the development of a leukemia, resembling the human acute promyelocytic leukemia, which is associated with a blast infiltration of several organs such as bone marrow, liver, and particularly the spleen.
    For the in vivo analysis one million leukemic cells (obtained from 129SvEv mice(52)) were injected intravenously into nonirradiated syngenic recipients. Mice were randomized in experimental groups of at least 6 mice, and the treatment started once blast cells are detected in the recipients’ peripheral blood (generally 10 days after injection). Compounds 14d and 14e were dissolved in a vehicle comprising 40% PEG 400 in 5% glucose solution and orally administered either 5 days per week for 2 weeks at the doses of 27 mg/kg or 3 days per week for 2 weeks at the dose of 45 mg/kg. 22 was dissolved in a vehicle comprising 40% PEG 400 in 5% glucose solution and intraperitoneally administered 5 days per week for 2 weeks at the dose of 0.0125 mg/kg as reported by Oryzon.(73)
    The survival of mice of the different experimental groups was analyzed and represented by a Kaplan–Meier survival plot. The pure 1S,2R-enantiomer 15 was then dissolved in a vehicle comprising 40% PEG 400 in a 5% glucose solution and orally administered 3 days per week for 3 weeks at the doses of 11.25 mg/kg and 22.5 mg/kg. The survival of the mice of the different experimental groups was analyzed as in the case of compound 14d and represented by a Kaplan–Meier survival plot.
    All animal studies were carried out in compliance with Italian Legislative Decree No. 116 dated January 27, 1992, and the European Communities Council Directive No. 86/609/EEC concerning the protection of animals used for experimental or other scientific purposes and according to Institutional Policy Regarding the Care and Use of Laboratory Animals (project specific license number 11/2012).

    1. 1
      Helin, K.; Dhanak, D. Chromatin proteins and modifications as drug targets Nature 2013, 502, 480– 488 DOI: 10.1038/nature12751
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      1
      Chromatin proteins and modifications as drug targets
      Helin, Kristian; Dhanak, Dashyant
      Nature (London, United Kingdom) (2013), 502 (7472), 480-488CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Nature Publishing Group)
      A review. A plethora of groundbreaking studies have demonstrated the importance of chromatin-assocd. proteins and post-translational modifications of histones, proteins and DNA (so-called epigenetic modifications) for transcriptional control and normal development. Disruption of epigenetic control is a frequent event in disease, and the first epigenetic-based therapies for cancer treatment have been approved. A generation of new classes of potent and specific inhibitors for several chromatin-assocd. proteins have shown promise in preclin. trials. Although the biol. of epigenetic regulation is complex, new inhibitors such as these will hopefully be of clin. use in the coming years.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhs1Krt77E&md5=ca3f12c6aaba31bb571095bacc02550c
    2. 2
      Jones, P. A.; Baylin, S. B. The epigenomics of cancer Cell 2007, 128, 683– 692 DOI: 10.1016/j.cell.2007.01.029
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      2
      The epigenomics of cancer
      Jones, Peter A.; Baylin, Stephen B.
      Cell (Cambridge, MA, United States) (2007), 128 (4), 683-692CODEN: CELLB5; ISSN:0092-8674. (Cell Press)
      A review. Aberrant gene function and altered patterns of gene expression are key features of cancer. Growing evidence shows that acquired epigenetic abnormalities participate with genetic alterations to cause this dysregulation. Here, we review recent advances in understanding how epigenetic alterations participate in the earliest stages of neoplasia, including stem/precursor cell contributions, and discuss the growing implications of these advances for strategies to control cancer.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXis12ju7k%253D&md5=78eac8ecc093f1aed0acbfd578f34717
    3. 3
      Rodriguez-Paredes, M.; Esteller, M. Cancer epigenetics reaches mainstream oncology Nat. Med. 2011, 17, 330– 339 DOI: 10.1038/nm.2305
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      3
      Cancer epigenetics reaches mainstream oncology
      Rodriguez-Paredes, Manuel; Esteller, Manel
      Nature Medicine (New York, NY, United States) (2011), 17 (3), 330-339CODEN: NAMEFI; ISSN:1078-8956. (Nature Publishing Group)
      A review. Epigenetics is one of the most promising and expanding fields in the current biomedical research landscape. Since the inception of epigenetics in the 1940s, the discoveries regarding its implications in normal and disease biol. have not stopped, compiling a vast amt. of knowledge in the past decade. The field has moved from just one recognized marker, DNA methylation, to a variety of others, including a wide spectrum of histone modifications. From the methodol. standpoint, the successful initial single gene candidate approaches have been complemented by the current comprehensive epigenomic approaches that allow the interrogation of genomes to search for translational applications in an unbiased manner. Most important, the discovery of mutations in the epigenetic machinery and the approval of the first epigenetic drugs for the treatment of subtypes of leukemias and lymphomas has been an eye-opener for many biomedical scientists and clinicians. Herein, we will summarize the progress in the field of cancer epigenetics research that has reached mainstream oncol. in the development of new biomarkers of the disease and new pharmacol. strategies.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXivVGgtb8%253D&md5=07b6faaddb8bce884261990dbc927331
    4. 4
      Black, J. C.; Van Rechem, C.; Whetstine, J. R. Histone lysine methylation dynamics: establishment, regulation, and biological impact Mol. Cell 2012, 48, 491– 507 DOI: 10.1016/j.molcel.2012.11.006
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      4
      Histone Lysine Methylation Dynamics: Establishment, Regulation, and Biological Impact
      Black, Joshua C.; Van Rechem, Capucine; Whetstine, Johnathan R.
      Molecular Cell (2012), 48 (4), 491-507CODEN: MOCEFL; ISSN:1097-2765. (Elsevier Inc.)
      A review. Histone lysine methylation has emerged as a crit. player in the regulation of gene expression, cell cycle, genome stability, and nuclear architecture. Over the past decade, a tremendous amt. of progress has led to the characterization of Me modifications and the lysine methyltransferases (KMTs) and lysine demethylases (KDMs) that regulate them. Here, we review the discovery and characterization of the KMTs and KDMs and the Me modifications they regulate. We discuss the localization of the KMTs and KDMs as well as the distribution of lysine methylation throughout the genome. We highlight how these data have shaped our view of lysine methylation as a key determinant of complex chromatin states. Finally, we discuss the regulation of KMTs and KDMs by proteasomal degrdn., posttranscriptional mechanisms, and metabolic status. We propose key questions for the field and highlight areas that we predict will yield exciting discoveries in the years to come.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XhslKqtLvM&md5=b9a8e9c29c630592f5413f7e36974735
    5. 5
      Greer, E. L.; Shi, Y. Histone methylation: a dynamic mark in health, disease and inheritance Nat. Rev. Genet. 2012, 13, 343– 357 DOI: 10.1038/nrg3173
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      5
      Histone methylation: a dynamic mark in health, disease and inheritance
      Greer, Eric L.; Shi, Yang
      Nature Reviews Genetics (2012), 13 (5), 343-357CODEN: NRGAAM; ISSN:1471-0056. (Nature Publishing Group)
      A review. Organisms require an appropriate balance of stability and reversibility in gene expression programs to maintain cell identity or to enable responses to stimuli; epigenetic regulation is integral to this dynamic control. Post-translational modification of histones by methylation is an important and widespread type of chromatin modification that is known to influence biol. processes in the context of development and cellular responses. To evaluate how histone methylation contributes to stable or reversible control, we provide a broad overview of how histone methylation is regulated and leads to biol. outcomes. The importance of appropriately maintaining or reprogramming histone methylation is illustrated by its links to disease and ageing and possibly to transmission of traits across generations.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XkvVGgsbo%253D&md5=478821755588725cf2659c61a61e489c
